attributes.description:
This section provides Machine Learning (ML) powered visualizations to help assess compliance with CCI-001050 and CCI-004618. These CCIs focus on identifying newly discovered threats and risks, and these visualizations analyze anomaly scores from an ML job that detects an unusual volume or type of new security signals.

To perform a component-level compliance assessment, utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard. Apply filters such as 'influencers.host.name: <your_component_name>' or 'influencers.source.ip: <ip_address>' to focus on a specific system or traffic source. The ML job establishes a baseline for normal security signal generation. A high anomaly score (e.g., 75 or above) signifies a substantial deviation, such as a sudden flood of new signal types, which could indicate a coordinated attack, a new attack vector being exploited, or a widespread misconfiguration.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050, CCI-004618] ML - New Security Signals Health Status

attributes.description:
Why this visualization works: It provides a direct, contextualized list of the most significant anomalies related to new security signals. Instead of just seeing a spike on a chart, an analyst can immediately see the hosts, users, and source/destination IPs that are contributing most to the anomaly, accelerating the investigation process.

How an analyst can use it: Filter and sort the table by 'anomaly_score' to focus on the highest-risk events. Examine the influencer columns to identify patterns. For example, are many anomalous signals originating from a single 'source.ip' or targeting a specific 'host.name'? This information is critical for pinpointing the source of a new threat or a widespread detection issue.
attributes.title: [CCI-001050, CCI-004618] ML - Detailed New Security Signal Anomalies

attributes.description:
This section helps you assess compliance with CCI-004618 by identifying threats to your systems. The visualizations below leverage Elastic SIEM's detection signals to provide a comprehensive view of the threat landscape.

**How to Perform a Component-Level Compliance Assessment:**
1.  Utilize the global filters at the top of the Kibana dashboard to focus on a specific system or component (e.g., apply a filter like `host.name: <your_component_name>`).
2.  Review the **Total Active Threats** metric for an immediate count of open security signals for that component.
3.  Analyze the **Threat Identification Trend** to understand the volume and timeline of threats. Look for spikes or sustained activity that may indicate a targeted attack or persistent issue.
4.  Examine the **Top Threats** visualizations to understand the nature of the threats. Are they focused on initial access, execution, or data exfiltration? This context is crucial for risk assessment.
5.  Use the **Detailed Threat Events** table to drill down into specific alerts for forensic investigation. This table provides the 'who, what, and where' for each identified threat.

By combining these views, you can build a detailed threat profile for each component, which is a foundational activity for any risk assessment as required by RA-3.
attributes.title: [CCI-004618] Identify Threats
attributes.visState: {"title":"[CCI-004618] Identify Threats","type":"markdown","aggs":[],"params":{"markdown":"# [CCI-004618] Identify Threats\n\n### Conduct a risk assessment, including identifying threats to the system.","fontSize":12,"openLinksInNewTab":false}}

attributes.description: This visualization displays the health status for CCI-004618 by monitoring the highest anomaly scores from its associated Machine Learning job, which detects unusual volumes of new security signals. A high anomaly score indicates a significant deviation from the baseline, suggesting newly identified threats.
attributes.title: [CCI-004618] Identify Threats ML

attributes.description:
This visualization provides a high-level, at-a-glance count of all security signals that are currently open and require investigation.

**Why this visualization works:**
It offers an immediate summary of the current threat backlog. This number serves as a key performance indicator for the security team's operational tempo and the overall health of the monitored components.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this metric as a starting point for daily assessments. A sudden, unexplained increase in this number should trigger an immediate investigation. Use it in conjunction with the trend and detailed visualizations to understand the context behind the total count.
attributes.title: [CCI-004618] Total Active Threats

attributes.description:
This visualization displays a time-series trend of open security signals, broken down by threat severity.

**Why this visualization works:**
It provides a dynamic view of threat activity over time, allowing for the identification of spikes or patterns. Visualizing when threats occur helps correlate them with other events and understand if you are facing a prolonged attack campaign or isolated incidents.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Look for sudden increases in threat counts, which could indicate the start of an attack. A consistent, high baseline of threats may suggest a widespread misconfiguration or a persistent adversary. Use the time range selector to zoom in on suspicious periods and correlate the findings with other data sources.
attributes.title: [CCI-004618] Threat Identification Trend by Severity (converted)

attributes.description:
This table provides a detailed, granular view of every open security signal, showing the raw data needed for deep-dive forensic analysis.

**Why this visualization works:**
It provides the ground-truth data behind all other visualizations. For any identified threat or anomaly, this table contains the specific details required to investigate, validate, and respond. It is the cornerstone of the threat identification process.

**How an analyst can use it:**
Use this table as the final step in an investigation. After identifying a trend or a high-level threat, find the corresponding raw events here. Sort by columns like `host.name` or `rule.name` to group related activity. Use the data in this table to pivot to other tools or to initiate incident response procedures.
attributes.title: [CCI-004618] Detailed Threat Events
